conclusion: Understanding velocity-time graph and acceleration as slope.
Determine slopes of curves at t1 to compare accelerations.
Object A's velocity decreases over time; Object B's velocity increases then decreases.
At t1, Object A's velocity is decreasing (negative slope); Object B's velocity is increasing (positive slope).
Different slopes at t1 mean different accelerations.
Mathematical consideration of slopes: Object A has negative dv/dt, Object B has positive dv/dt at t1.
a(t1) for Object A is negative, a(t1) for Object B is positive, so accelerations are not equal.
Area under curve gives displacement, not relevant for acceleration.
Object A's curve is concave up; Object B's curve is concave down then up.
Reaffirmation that Object A is decelerating and Object B is accelerating at t1.
Consideration of specific values at t1 is difficult without numerical data.
Conclusion based on curve shapes: slopes at t1 are different.
Final conclusion: Objects A and B do not have the same acceleration at t1.
